did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: The Bloom Southwest Jewish Archives videocassettes consists of videocassettes of both professionally and non-professionally produced programs and interviews which are relevant either to the history of Jews who settled in the American desert southwest or to general Jewish topics

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: University of Arizona Libraries, Special Collections

prefercite.head: Credit Line
prefercite.p: Bloom Southwest Jewish Archives videocassettes (SJA 008). University of Arizona Library Special Collections.

arrangement.head: Organization
arrangement.p: The video tapes have been arranged alphabetically according to the title of the production or the subject matter of the tape's content. Tapes should be requested by number.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Professional and amateur productions of programs and interviews which are relevant either to the history of Jews who settled in the American desert southwest or to general Jewish topics. The bulk of the tapes describe the historical situation of Jews of Sephardic (viz., Spanish) background and present speculations about the identities of their descendants in the Americas. The tapes are particularly relevant to discussions of persons thought to be descendants of forcibly converted Spanish Jews who fled Spain for the New World after the expulsion of 1492.
Note: both the video and the audio quality of the tapes varies considerably. All the tapes are V.H.S. format.
19 video tapes. Program number 1 contains three tapes. Tape number 17 contains two programs.
Discussions of family history with Herb, Dave, and Ted Bloom. On the second and third tapes they are joined by Lanie Aarons,
Lecture by Reid Heller, sponsored by the Dallas Historical Society commemorating the 400th yahrtzeit(death anniversary) of a poet killed in the Mexican Inquisition. Poor audio quality
Description of the history and mission of the Bloom Southwest Jewish Archives from its inception to the establishment of its WEB site. Narrated by Melissa Amado and Stuart Glogoff,

did.unittitle: Congregation Anshei Israel's 5th Street Opening, No date

scopecontent.p: Gathering of people at Tucson's Congregation Anshei Israel's new synagogue and the procession of the Torah scrolls into the new sanctuary. No audio,
Program on the so-called "Crypto-Jews"produced for the KUAT, Tucson, television program "Arizona Illustrated." 12 minutes
Davis (a Spiegelberg granddaughter) relates her recollections of the Spiegelberg family in New Mexico,
Abraham Chanin interviews Stewart and Morris Udall while hosting his program "Eyewitness to History,"

did.unittitle: "Girona, The Mother of Israel: The Jews of Catalonia," No date

scopecontent.p: Describes the history of the Jews of Girona, Spain (in the region of Catalonia), until the time of the expulsion in 1492,
Same content as Tape 5
Describes the process of building Israel Tennis Centers throughout Israel and the rationale for doing so

Family members tell their history and how they or their ancestors journeyed from Poland, to Cuba, and to the United States (including Tucson) in reaction to the Polish pogroms of the early 20th century and to the Cuban Revolution. 2 hours, 32 minutes
Libo summarizes aspects of his 1984 book "We Lived There Too," which describes the history of Jews in the United Statesand their movement westward into the frontier
A production for the television program "Colores" which describes the history of the Jews in Las Vegas, New Mexico
A photographic montage of Tucson's Jewish history produced for the Jewish Federation of Southern Arizona on the occasion of its anniversary
Describes a project of the Arizona Historical Society for preserving the histories of Arizona's lawyers and judges
Speakers at a conference discuss how their (known or supposed) Sephardic Jewish ancestry has impacted them. Poor quality

did.unittitle: "Trees Cry for Rain: A Sephardic Journey",1993

scopecontent.p: Members of a family describe living as Jews in Turkey and later in St. Louis, Missouri
Describes how Jewish immigrants to Argentina in the nineteenth century co-existed with the local "Gauchos" and even adopted some of their practices. 30 minutes
